aboutPage.heading: About Max Mendes
bio: I'm Max, a full-stack web developer based in Częstochowa, Poland. I build modern business websites, e-commerce stores, and AI-powered web applications — with a focus on clean, maintainable code, strong performance, and real-world usability.

My role is technical: I write code and turn ideas into working products. I implement interfaces using proven UI patterns and component libraries like shadcn/ui and Tailwind CSS, with a strong focus on speed, SEO optimization, and scalability. I also integrate AI capabilities using OpenAI and Anthropic APIs—tools I've used in production to build features like smart content generation, automated workflows, and intelligent data processing. Design and branding are outside my scope — I focus entirely on development.

My process is structured and practical. I start with research—understanding the business goal, competitors, and technical requirements. Then I create low-fidelity prototypes in Figma to map user flows and features. After that, I build production-ready code using React and Next.js, handle deployment, optimization, and iteration based on feedback.

My biggest project, FlowMate, is an AI-powered email management platform that handles multi-platform broadcasting and smart content generation. It took 300+ hours to build and taught me how to architect production SaaS applications with authentication, payments, AI integration, and real user data at scale.

I'm available for Polish businesses that need modern websites or online stores, as well as UK and US companies looking for a full-stack developer. I'm fluent in English and work comfortably across time zones.

sections.title: What SaaS Development Means
paragraphs: SaaS development is about building subscription-based software that users rely on continuously, not a one-time website or a simple web app. A SaaS product manages accounts, permissions, data isolation, and recurring payments across many customers at once. This is known as multi-tenancy—your platform serves multiple businesses or users while keeping their data separate and secure.
Unlike regular websites, SaaS products must handle onboarding, billing cycles, upgrades, cancellations, and long-term maintenance. These are business-critical systems, not just interfaces.

sections.title: What's Included in This Service
paragraphs: I build SaaS platforms that cover the full product lifecycle. Projects can include secure user authentication with email/password, OAuth, and social logins; subscription management with Stripe; and database structures designed for multi-tenant data. Admin dashboards allow you to manage users, plans, and usage without manual work.

Email notifications and onboarding flows guide users through signup, activation, and billing events. APIs are built to support integrations with third-party services or future mobile and partner applications. Built to add features without rebuilding the foundation.

sections.title: Who This Is For and Use Cases

It also fits businesses launching subscription platforms or internal SaaS tools that replace spreadsheets or manual workflows. Common use cases include productivity tools, B2B platforms, analytics dashboards, and subscription-based services.

FlowMate—the SaaS platform I built for email management—handles multi-provider authentication, async processing (background tasks that don't slow down the UI), AI integrations, and Stripe subscriptions at production scale. It demonstrates how these systems work together in a real product.

sections.title: Why performance and SEO matter for business
paragraphs: Website performance and SEO are directly tied to business outcomes. Slow websites lose users before they convert, while search engines rank faster, more reliable pages higher. Google's Core Web Vitals are official ranking factors, which means page speed and stability affect how visible your site is in search results.

Even small delays matter—industry data shows that a one-second slowdown can reduce conversions by around 7%. With mobile-first indexing, Google primarily evaluates the mobile version of your site, making mobile performance critical. The goal of optimization is not technical perfection for its own sake, but more qualified traffic, better user engagement, and higher conversion rates.

sections.title: What's included: Performance optimization
paragraphs: I focus on measurable improvements to how fast and stable your website feels to real users. This includes improving Core Web Vitals metrics such as LCP (Largest Contentful Paint), FID/INP (interaction responsiveness), and CLS (layout stability).

Page speed is optimized through image compression, modern formats, lazy loading, and reducing unnecessary JavaScript. Code splitting and asset optimization ensure users load only what they need. Caching strategies and CDN usage reduce server response times, while database queries are reviewed to eliminate bottlenecks. Each project includes before-and-after measurements using tools like Lighthouse and real-user metrics, so improvements are clear and verifiable.

sections.title: What's included: Technical SEO improvements
paragraphs: SEO optimization starts with a technical audit to identify crawlability and indexing issues that limit visibility. I address problems such as broken internal links, duplicate content signals, incorrect redirects, and poor URL structures.

Structured data (Schema.org) is implemented to improve eligibility for rich results and enhanced listings. Meta titles and descriptions are optimized for clarity, relevance, and click-through rate—not keyword stuffing. Server-side rendering and correct handling of JavaScript ensure search engines can fully index your content. The result is a technically sound foundation that supports long-term SEO growth.

sections.title: Who this is for
paragraphs: This service fits businesses with slow-loading websites, sites with poor Google rankings despite good content, e-commerce stores with high bounce rates, and companies losing mobile traffic. It's also suited for websites built on WordPress or outdated platforms needing optimization, sites that failed Core Web Vitals assessment, and businesses wanting to improve conversion rates through speed improvements.

sections.title: How the work is delivered
paragraphs: Optimization work is handled directly by one developer, without agency layers. The process starts with a comprehensive audit covering both performance and SEO issues. I identify specific problems, prioritize fixes based on impact, implement optimizations, and validate results with measurable data. Changes are implemented carefully to avoid regressions.
Based in Częstochowa, Poland. Available for optimization projects across Poland and internationally.

sections.title: What AI integration means for business
paragraphs: AI integration means adding focused, intelligent features to products you already run—not rebuilding everything or chasing trends. In practice, AI can help automate repetitive work, classify and route information, improve search relevance, generate summaries, or assist users with clearer responses. The difference between useful AI and "AI for AI's sake" is intent: each feature starts with a specific problem. The goal is to reduce manual effort, improve user experience, or unlock a capability that wasn't feasible before. This is not about replacing teams or promising perfect accuracy. It is about practical gains where machine learning genuinely adds value.

sections.title: What's included: common AI features
paragraphs: Projects can include text classification and categorization, content generation and summarization, and intelligent search with semantic matching. Other frequent needs are recommendations and personalization, image recognition and processing, and natural language processing for user input. Automated responses and chatbots are used when appropriate—typically as assistance, not full automation. Data analysis and pattern recognition can surface trends or anomalies that are hard to detect with rules alone. Each feature is scoped to a clear outcome, measured against real usage, and designed to fail safely.

sections.title: Technical implementation and providers
paragraphs: I integrate with established AI providers such as OpenAI, Anthropic, and Google, as well as selected open-source models when appropriate. Work includes API integration, prompt design for consistent outputs, and cost management so usage stays predictable. Error handling and fallbacks are essential—AI is probabilistic and needs guardrails. Data privacy, security, and performance are considered from the start, including caching and asynchronous processing.
FlowMate uses AI integrations for email classification and smart response suggestions, handling real-world variability in email content.

paragraphs: This service fits businesses with repetitive manual tasks that AI can assist, products needing intelligent search or recommendations, and customer support teams that want AI help without replacing humans. Content platforms benefit from summarization and categorization; e-commerce can add personalization; SaaS products can introduce smart features that improve retention.
Common examples include document classification, inquiry routing, content moderation, and product recommendations—implemented with clear limits and measurable impact.
Based in Częstochowa, Poland. Available for AI integration projects locally and internationally.

links.text: Questions about AI integration costs or process? Check the FAQ →

sections.title: Approach and Considerations
paragraphs: I start with a narrow use case, not "add AI everywhere." A small proof of concept validates whether AI actually improves the workflow. Implementation is gradual, with fallbacks when results are uncertain. Costs are tracked early—AI API calls scale with usage. If a rule-based solution is better, I recommend it. The key question is always the same: will this intelligent feature materially improve the product?

faqPage.intro: How we work together, what to expect, and what happens after launch.

items.question: What services do you provide?
items.answer: I build production web applications: business websites, SaaS platforms, custom e-commerce systems, and AI-powered features. Everything is built with React, Next.js, and TypeScript — production-ready from day one, built to scale.

items.question: What don't you build?
items.answer: I focus exclusively on custom software development — websites, web apps, and SaaS built with React and Next.js. Design, branding, and marketing are outside my scope. If you need those services, I can recommend specialists.

items.question: Do you work solo or with a team?
items.answer: I work as a solo full-stack developer and handle the entire build myself. You work directly with the person writing your code — one point of contact from start to finish.

items.question: Can you handle both Polish and international clients?
items.answer: Yes. I work with companies in Poland and international clients in the UK and US. Communication is in English or Polish, and Polish content is reviewed with my wife to ensure natural language and accuracy.

items.question: How do we start working together?
items.answer: We start with a conversation about your problem and goals. I review the requirements, ask technical questions, and propose a clear scope, timeline, and pricing before any work begins.
items.linkText: Get in touch to discuss your project

items.question: What's your development process?
items.answer: I start by defining requirements and technical architecture, then move into iterative development with regular checkpoints. Features are built and tested as we go, with adjustments based on your feedback.

items.question: How long does a typical project take?
items.answer: Simple business websites take 3-5 weeks. SaaS platforms or custom e-commerce systems typically take 8-12 weeks, depending on integrations, database complexity, and feature requirements.

items.question: How do we communicate during the project?
items.answer: Direct communication via email, Slack, or calls—whatever works for you. Weekly check-ins keep you updated on progress, blockers, and next steps. No unnecessary meetings or status reports.

items.question: What's your pricing structure?
items.answer: Most projects are fixed-price based on a clearly defined scope. For ongoing development or evolving products, I offer monthly development retainers.

items.question: Do you require a deposit?
items.answer: Yes. Projects start with a 30-50% deposit, with the remainder paid in milestones or at delivery. This keeps timelines predictable and protects both sides.

items.question: What payment methods do you accept?
items.answer: I accept bank transfers (SWIFT/SEPA for international clients) and online payment platforms. All transactions are straightforward and compliant with EU regulations.

items.question: Can I pay in installments?
items.answer: Yes, for larger projects. Payments are split into clear milestones tied to delivered work, so you're paying for real progress.

items.question: What tech stack do you use?
items.answer: React, Next.js, and TypeScript for frontend and full-stack applications. PostgreSQL or Supabase for databases, with additional tools based on your specific requirements. This stack delivers fast, secure, maintainable software that scales without major rewrites.

items.question: Can you work with my existing codebase?
items.answer: Yes, if the codebase is reasonably maintained and documented. I'll review it first and tell you honestly whether it makes sense to extend it, refactor parts, or start fresh.

items.question: Do you handle hosting and deployment?
items.answer: Yes. I handle production deployment, environment configuration, and performance optimization. Your application launches stable, monitored, and ready for real users—not just pushed live and forgotten.

items.question: How do you ensure my site is secure and performant?
items.answer: I follow modern security practices for authentication and data handling. Server-side rendering, optimized images, and proper caching are built in by default. Core Web Vitals and load times are treated as requirements, not extras.

items.question: How much do AI features cost in practice?
items.answer: AI integration has two parts: one-time development cost and ongoing API usage costs. Development covers designing, integrating, and testing the AI feature, while API costs depend on how often users trigger AI actions. I explain both upfront so there are no surprises later.

items.question: How are AI costs kept predictable and under control?
items.answer: AI costs are managed through caching, request limits, and only calling AI when it adds real value. Common results can be reused instead of regenerated, which significantly reduces usage. I also design features so costs scale with business value, not background noise.

items.question: What happens to my data when using AI providers?
items.answer: Data sent to AI providers is processed by external services like OpenAI or Anthropic, so they technically see the input. I minimize what is sent, avoid unnecessary personal data, and follow provider privacy options where available. If strict data control is required, we discuss alternatives or limits before building anything.

items.question: How reliable and accurate is AI in real products?
items.answer: AI is probabilistic, not deterministic, so it will sometimes be wrong or inconsistent. That's why I always build fallbacks, validation, and clear UI states for uncertain results. You should expect AI to assist and speed things up, not to be 100% correct.

items.question: Which AI provider should I use: OpenAI, Anthropic, or something else?
items.answer: The best provider depends on the task, cost profile, and reliability requirements. Some models are better at structured classification, others at longer reasoning or safer outputs. I usually test providers on your specific use case and choose based on results, not brand names.

items.question: What happens after the project launches?
items.answer: I monitor stability after launch, fix any early issues, and ensure everything works as expected. You're not left alone with a fresh deployment.

items.question: Do you offer ongoing maintenance?
items.answer: Yes. I offer maintenance and development plans covering updates, bug fixes, performance improvements, and new features as your product evolves.

items.question: Can you train my team to manage the site?
items.answer: Yes. I provide documentation and walkthroughs so your team understands the system and can manage content or basic operations confidently.

items.question: What if I need new features later?
items.answer: New features can be added as separate projects or as part of a maintenance agreement. Clean code means extending functionality is usually straightforward and predictable.
